channel.title: Dream Defenders
channel.description: We are young, powerful people organizing towards a new vision for safety away from prisons.

item.title: Palestine & Internationalism Committee
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
The Dream Defenders have now led two delegations to Palestine. Delegates have a chance to see the land and occupation up close, while engaging in dialogue and relationship building with Palestinians on the ground engaged in the struggle for justice.

...here we are again, declaring that our liberation is tied together...

DDPalestine is a part of the resurgence of internationalism within the US based movement for justice, especially inspired by the connections of Black & Palestinian liberation. Historically this movement has existed for decades, with no shortage of figures exchanging commitments of solidarity, and here we are again, declaring that our liberation is tied together.

Palestine is the site of a continued settler colonial project, the state of Israel. The colonial project was born out of a political ideology called Zionism, established in the late 19th century. Zionism as a movement was born out of Europe and they were seeking to establish a homeland for Jews outside of Europe, and after looking at several locations in Africa and South America, they settled on Palestine. While of course the native, indigenous population which was mostly Muslim and Christian with a smaller Jewish population, rejected this colonial entity, the international community led by the British ushered it into statehood. In 1948 the state of Israel was declared on top of stolen Palestinian land, with zionist militias committing massacres and forced evictions, they immediately ethnically cleansing over 750,000 Palestinians from the lands, and internally displacing thousands more. 

That was the story leading up to and through 1948, and the colonial entity of Israel has only fortified itself more by taking control over more territory while keeping minimal Palestinians. Home demolitions, evictions, administrative detention, abuse/arrest of children in military courts, checkpoints and more are the Palestinian reality, all while Israeli settlements, considered illegal by the entire world continue to be built atop Palestinian land, taking both home and water from the native population. Palestinians living within Israel continue to be discriminated against at all levels of citizenship, right down to the annual threats of politicians for their passports to be stripped and then deported.

Palestinians in Gaza live in the world's largest open air prison with Israel controlling land/air/sea and controlling everything that comes in and out. Israel routinely develops its latest military weaponry by attacking the civilian population of Gaza. After every Israeli assault against Gaza their sales have been a part of the package. 

One page and a couple of paragraphs are not nearly enough, this is more of a quick shot of the context, and we would suggest both reading several documented sources as well as visiting Palestine for yourself.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe title="Solidarity Demonstration in Nazareth : Ferguson to Palestine" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/116675694?dnt=1&app_id=122963" width="500" height="281" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Blacked Out History
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
Blacked Out History Month is an effort to highlight individuals, moments, and important facts throughout history that were left out of our history classes but made a tremendous impact on the world that we live in today.

February is the one month out of the year dedicated to honoring and remembering Black history. As Dream Defenders, we revere this history and know that every day in our work we stand on the shoulders of giants.

We are also aware that there is no such thing as an isolated “Black history”.

Our struggle has been inspired by, linked to, and shaped by the struggles of many who also see their histories forgotten. For this reason, we dedicate every February to shining a light on our Blacked Out Histories.

View Blacked Out History Tumblr: ddblackedouthistory.tumblr.com/

Follow #BlackedOutHistory: check the hashtag on Instagram.

item.title: GEO Group
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
Florida has the 3rd largest prison system in the country and houses the largest private prison corporation called GEO Group.

In the past 20 years, GEO group has given 8.7 million to politicians and have had influence over Florida legislation.

In the 2018 elections, Dream Defenders engaged in a campaign targeting GEO Group, and through direct actions, bird dogging and culture shifting, Dream Defenders got the Florida Democratic Party to pass a resolution discouraging candidates from taking private prison funding, and got an additional 30 candidates to sign a pledge to not take private prison funds.

See more at www.geocages.com.

item.title: Bernie 2020
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
For the first time in our organization’s history, we took a chance by endorsing a Presidential candidate.

We built an endorsement process rooted in our vision of true democracy and equity. For 6 months, our chapters met monthly to look at all of the candidates platforms in relationship to our political agenda, the Freedom Papers. We spent time analyzing policies, track records and debating which candidates best aligned with our vision for the future. At the end of the endorsement process, 90% of our members voted for Bernie. 

Then, we knocked on thousands of doors, made over 100,000 phone calls in every major city in Florida and talked to our communities about the things we all deserve: healthcare, education, debt relief, higher wages, and a re-shaping of our criminal legal and immigration systems.

And at the end of our efforts in our home state, we have more members and relationships than we’ve ever had because of this work. 

More info at: dreamdefendersfight.org/

Follow our Fight Pac on Instagram: dreamdefendersfight

item.title: Free the Block
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
At this moment, thousands of Black and brown people are sitting in local jails while they await their trial simply because they can’t afford to pay bail.

These people have not been convicted of anything, they are sitting in a cage because they can’t afford to pay for their freedom.

Free the Block is a campaign to end money bail and pre-trial detention in Miami-Dade County and Tampa. Inspired campaigns for criminal justice and bail reform happening all over the country, Dream Defenders and other partner organizations are collecting thousands of petition signatures to make the case for adopting alternatives to money bail and pre-trial detention that are far more effective and humane. 

Sign the petition: https://secure.everyaction.com/eI1wleCteEiir1WbcWm_mg2

Find out more: https://www.freetheblock.org/

item.title: Trauma Response Center
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
The Trauma Response Center is a Dream Defenders initiative to address community violence and trauma outside of the police state. The lack of services in our community and increased policing is having devastating effects on our generation. Through “The Center”, we are disrupting the belief that the police can meet our needs and demonstrating the alternative, we are providing our community with tools to address violence and harm and providing healing spaces for people through direct service, arts and culture. 

“The Center” will be housed at Belafonte Tacolcy Center, a historic youth community center in Liberty City. Following its legacy, the Center will make it a safe haven for youth, and a hub for community services and abolitionist organizing. Some examples of the services offered include: free legal services, violence interruption, mental health counseling, stop the bleed training as well as skills training and job placement, arts programming and more! 

Dream Defenders has organized a coalition of groups to make this come to life: Dade County Street Response, Smoke Signals, Roots Black House, and (F)empower are some of the groups involved.

item.title: State Attorney Campaigns
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
State Attorneys are the most powerful actors in the criminal justice system. In 2020, all state attorneys across the state of Florida are up for re-election. After a long history of Florida DAs targeting Black and brown communities through “tough on crime” tactics, we are launching campaigns that target state attorneys, demanding they respond to our vision of safety and delegitimizing their tough-on-crime approach.

We will be releasing report cards for state attorneys across Florida and recruiting and/or endorsing candidates in some cases.

item.title: Florida People's Bailout
item.dc:creator: caitlynmcclure
item.content:encoded:
All Floridians deserve to be safe and healthy. We deserve safe space to shelter, food in our bellies, the means to take care of our families and the ability to seek care when we’re sick. 

Find What You Need
Volunteer to Keep Your Community Safe

For too long, we’ve watched Florida’s politicians put the profits of big corporations over our wellbeing and now, in the midst of a global crisis, their priorities are becoming all the more clear. 

Corona Virus is spreading quickly and infecting people all over our state. Meanwhile, thousands of Floridians are out of work with more than 70,000 people filed for unemployment in the last week alone. While we are struggling to pay our bills and take care of our families, Governor Ron Desantis is pretending like nothing is wrong at all -- at the request of big business.

DeSantis and politicians like him aren’t prepared or willing to do what’s needed to save the lives of millions of Floridians right now. To them, their corporate friends will always come before the rest of us. And while they refuse to act, our hospitals are about to be overwhelmed, more and more people are dying and even more Floridians are wondering how they will pay for their next meal or their rent.  

But it doesn’t have to be this way. Our state has all the resources it needs to see us through this crisis: to make sure every Floridian has access to testing and care, a safe place to stay, and paid sick leave so no one has to decide between getting sick and paying the bills.

THERE IS ENOUGH FOR ALL OF US TO GET THROUGH THIS TIME OF CRISIS TOGETHER AND IT IS OUR RIGHT TO.

Ron DeSantis, the Florida Legislature and local leaders across the state need to Pass a #PeoplesBailout NOW. As nurses, delivery drivers and grocery clerks keep our state running, we need our local and state government officials to step up to  the plate and pass a relief and recovery package to address the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. 

It is not the time for half measures or piece-meal plans. We need immediate, bold, and comprehensive action to ensure the containment of Corona Virus and the health of everyone in our state. 

Find What You Need
Volunteer to Keep Your Community Safe

HEALTH IS THE TOP PRIORITY, FOR ALL PEOPLE, WITH NO EXCEPTIONS.

Spotlight on Ron DeSantis

Governor Desantis’ Record of Inaction on Covid-19:

  • Refused to issue a statewide stay-at-home order
  • Refused to close crowded beaches while thousands of people were in the state for Spring Break
  • He was slower than at least 35 other governors to suspend in-person dining at restaurants and behind at least 22 in closing gyms and fitness studios.
  • He still has not ordered non-essential business to close
  • Told people to go out to vote during Florida’s primary after other states had moved theirs. Made no effort to make the polls safer
  • Meanwhile, he was awarding businesses loans in preparation for the virus
  • Like his predecessor Rick Scott, DeSantis has refused to expand Medicaid 
  • His party members in the Florida Senate proposed tens of millions in tax breaks for big corporations and sports teams (that are now shut down due to the virus) before they thought up any relief plans for the people in Florida.

Ron DeSantis has been doing plenty, but not in the interest of our health and safety.
